Mr Strachey 
Nor. 360 Abridgt.
P.968.
1. An account of ye Strata in Coal Mines &c.
By John Strachey Esq. F.R.S.

It was some Time since that in a Letter 
to One of the Members of this Society, I gave an Account 
of the Severall Strata of Earths and Mineralls found in 
some of the Coal Works in <u>Somersetshire <\u>, which was printed 
in One of Your Transactions. But there is one great 
Error in the Print, for whereas I said that in those Parts 
they never meet with <u>Freestone <\u> over the Coal, the Printer 
by Mistake calls it <u>Firestone <\u>, whereas <u>Firestone <\u> is 
always found in those Mines, contrary to the Works in 
<u>Staffordshire<\u>, <u>Newcastle <\u>, and <u>Scotland <\u> , where <u>Freestone <\u>
does indeed lye over the Coal. I have farther observed the 
<u>Strata<\u> of Stone, Clay, and Marle, of the interjacent Hills,
where, under the black Marle, lyes a Spongy, Yellowish Earth,
All this lyes above the Red Soyl which I have said is gene-
-rally the Surface of the Valleys where the Coal is found. And 
as this Red Mould on the Surface degenerates in to Malm
or Loom, so towards the North West, beyond or without the 
Veins of Coal, about <u>Winford <\u> in the same County, it turns 
to Ruddle or Red Okre, used cheifly for marking of Sheep, 
and for ground Colours or primeing, insteed of Spanish 
Brown, and often Counterfeits Bol.Armon.
But as I never heard any Coal was found to the West or 
South of Mendip hills, so <u>Cotswold <\u> to the North East, and 
the Chalk Hills of Marlboro Downs and Salisbury Plains 
seem to sett Bounds to the Coal Country to the East and South
